reviews.advice: Just keep doing what you're doing.  You're providing a lot of new workers a great opportunity to get their careers started, while making yourselves very rich off their underpaid labor.  Why would you change a thing?
reviews.cons: Bad place to be past age 26.  Absurdly low pay, long hours, low chance of career development.  They don't want you to stay past 3 years.  Sooner or later, getting paid in parties and a trip to Europe every year doesn't cut it when you're still looking for roommates every year and making no progress on your college debt.
reviews.pros: Good place to start your career out of college.  Lots of young people, lots of great parties and some free travel.  Good culture and respectable mission.

reviews.advice: Create actual opportunities for career growth at the Denver office. Restructure the commission to actually be paid per traveler more often than at the end of each year.
reviews.cons: Low Pay. No room for growth or career movement (especially in their Denver office). The commission structure isn't per sale, instead you're rewarded if you meet an arbitrary goal set by your manager all or nothing. The company touts its "great culture" but really they just pay for drinks occasionally. No real mentorship or development. The company is clearly okay with huge employee turnover as many (if not most) new hires leave within a year.

employerResponses.response: Thank you for taking the time to share your feedback with us. We are disappointed to hear you are feeling unfulfilled in your role. As a current EF Denver employee, we would greatly welcome your insights on these opportunities for improvement. I encourage you to talk with the EF Denver central recruitment and development team to share your feedback around development and professional growth. We appreciate your candor and hope we will have the opportunity to work with you on making EF a better place to work, grow and develop.

reviews.pros: They have decent health insurance (although they make it sound AMAZING in the onboarding process). You typically get the chance to travel on one of their products once a year.
reviews.summary: A sales company that will try to sell you on them

reviews.advice: Create professional development and training programs so that employees can continue to learn new skills and grow.  Pay must increase in order to avoid the high turn-over.
reviews.cons: The pay is way below average.  This is off-set a bit by the free travel opportunities and benefits, but that doesn't pay the bills.  No room to move up, only laterally.  No professional development system in place or mentoring/training programs established.
reviews.pros: Fun/collaborative/energetic work environment.  All departments work toward one mission.  Excellent benefits (generous vacation time, 401(k) matching, health, dental, etc.).  Employees feel cared for by management.  Transparency is big with senior management.  Teams form strong friendships at work.  You can feel good about your work because it's helping kids travel the world and they come back transformed.
reviews.summary: Fun/collaborative environment, work that helps people, very low pay

reviews.advice: Pay Traveler Support a competitive wage or make the better paid and more supported TCs more responsibilities for what they are already paid.
reviews.cons:
The pay is not truly competitive especially considering company offices are centrally located in major cities (Austin, Denver, Boston, etc.) but the employees cannot afford to live independently nearby.
The work is not just customer-facing but also has become the "backbone" of the company where other departments require Traveler Support Specialists to also maintain good communication with group leaders that the Sales partners have not followed up with. Traveler Support Specialists are given fewer incentives (including fewer travel opportunities and incentives based on merit and fewer company-wide salary adjustments year over year. The turnover rate is high.

employerResponses.response: Thank you for taking the time to share with us your feedback. It is great to know you have enjoyed the work environment, travel perks, and benefits.  We are saddened, however, to hear you have felt that the work in your role was not appropriate to the salary. While we are continuing to review our salary structure, we also want to ensure our team members feel supported in their roles and maintain a healthy work-life balance. We always want to improve and receiving feedback is essential to this effort. Thank you for sharing with us. We wish you the best in your future career.

reviews.pros: Friendly work environment, amazing but costly benefits, company-sponsored international travel, and local events
reviews.summary: Involved work at a fun company with poor pay

reviews.advice: Be more honest about the job description. And I think many employees would rather have higher pay than all the parties and perks.
reviews.cons:
In the Denver office, there is very little room for lateral movement within the company - no opportunities unless you're willing to relocate to Boston. 
The job description is not what it's turned out to be. All positions (even if it's not called a Sales position) is very very heavily based in sales which makes up most of your salary (which base is very very low).
reviews.pros:
The social aspect is amazing - all like-minded fun individuals who love travel.
The perks are awesome - health insurance, dental, travel, etc.
It does give you very good cores skills and experience with big business, various computer programs, customer service, etc.
reviews.summary: Good experience out of college, doesn't lead to a career

reviews.advice: Invest in employees who are hardworking and get superb feedback from customers.  Establish realistic career paths for those looking to gain experience in addition to sales.  Make sure all employees have the chance to staff customer events when possible, so it's not the same people every time.  Evaluate to make sure the pay is truly reflective of each employee's actual job tasks and hours.  Keep up the fun and quirky atmosphere and mission that persists throughout the office!
reviews.cons: It's a heavily sales based and pressuring environment most of the time.  Managers tend to favor and promote employees who have a loud personality, despite their working ability which gets very frustrating.  They expect a lot to be done without a lot of given direction.  A lot of times you can feel micromanaged as daily reports of your accomplishments are sent out to the team. If you're a dedicated employee, often times the amount of work you have to do to truly make the customer content requires staying late well beyond your hours. For most positions that aren't management, you're asked to work shifts, so it's not a standard 9-6pm job.  This can be convenient sometimes to accommodate appointments, etc., just something to be aware of.  Lots of turnover.  Also, there's ironically not a lot of opportunity to travel - you have to really make yourself known to get any sort of chance to travel to an offsite event (that's not already a company wide event) which means you have to be very persistent.  Salary is very low for the amount of work you're expected to do and still maintain the quality customers are expecting.  Bonuses are extremely difficult to achieve unless you're an aggressive seller.  As much as managers try to help you grow your career at EF, the reality is it is challenging to find a true career path if you're not interested in growing into a sales related position.  Rewards for hitting goals were usually happy hours which get old quickly and aren't motivating.

employerResponses.response:
Wow - thank you for this thoughtful feedback.  It's incredibly valued!

You raise great points about the importance of investing in our terrific staff and demonstrating career paths.  Because we are a flat, decentralized company -- which generally allows us to move fast, be flexible and create growth opportunities within staffs' roles -- demonstrating a "linear" career path has been a challenge.  One of the tactics we've employed to address this challenge is facilitating regular meetings among the leadership teams from all of our businesses to discuss their key open roles and the internal talent who are ready for their next challenge and might be a fit for those roles.  We hold a similar meeting that is attended by line managers and is designed to achieve the same outcome.  In the Boston office alone, these and other efforts have produced two new opportunities each week, including promotions, product moves, office moves and even international moves.  

Thanks again for sharing your experience!

-- Mike Kaufman, Sr. Director of People Operations

reviews.pros: Awesome people, fun atmosphere in a super modern building that's like a glorified Ikea right on the Charles River in Cambridge, MA and in an accessible location.  Epic company parties, kickoff events and team outings in Boston and beyond (there's no holding back!). Casual and productive working atmosphere where everyone's approachable no matter their job title - they encourage you to get up from your desk to go talk to other departments instead of emailing back and forth.  Diverse personalities of people make the team interesting and there's always someone to talk to who you can bounce ideas off of or get work advice from.  My favorite benefits included: 3 weeks paid vacation your first year and 4 weeks in your second year and beyond, informative career building events from senior managers about once a month, free language classes (one class per week for an 8 week session), generous 401K match, and a very inclusive health insurance coverage.  Depending on the product, if you're there for over 2 years, your flight to visit the EF world headquarters in Luzern, Switzerland for 2 days may be covered, which means you could make a Eurotrip out of that visit.  Back at the Boston office, there's a bar and restaurant on the main level, so it's convenient to socialize with co-workers after hours, especially as new people join the team.  It's a great place to start your career and get a feel for a professional office environment with a casual twist.
reviews.summary: Great place to start, challenging to find a true career

reviews.cons: If you have limited physical mobility, there can be less options to move up in the company. The flat structure is great for the customer and it gives you great autonomy in your role, but if you are someone looking for a ladder to climb and lots of title changes, this is not the place for you. If you are able to make your own way, there are lots of options.
reviews.pros: Challenging roles, lots of freedom and responsibility up front. For people who are driven and self-motivated, there is a lot of room to grow within your role and take on new challenges. As an international company, those willing to relocate have lots of options. Great benefits package with the best health care I've ever seen, lots of vacation time and travel opportunities.

reviews.advice: Your reputation for low pay and lack of regard for employees is getting a reputation around town. It's embarrassing to say you work for EF in Boston
reviews.cons: This is a company that takes young, impressional college grads and convinces them that they're making sacrifices on pay, work/life balance and respect for the sake of a broader mission of global education. The truth is EF gouges customers with huge margins and employees are making these sacrifices so the family at the helm can become richer and richer. Any non-executive employee (read: non-Harvard Business School grad) is simply a number and they're alarmingly transparent about that. If you want to make the world a better place, go work at a non-profit and if you want to be respected or valued in your workplace, go work pretty much anywhere else in the city
reviews.pros: In most divisions you can travel once a year
reviews.summary: Don't Be Sucked In By The "Mission"

reviews.advice: This is teaching, it's not making widgets. Stop acting like an educational institution if you don't want to be one.
reviews.cons:
You're not really there to teach English. You're there to sell classes. You can get great student reviews by heaping praise upon students and the office will love you.

Horrible, horrible support from the Boston office. If you have an emergency and follow procedure, they will still mark you as not showing and you can lose a week's work. You get regular pay raises -- but you also get fewer scheduled hours after you get that raise. People assigned to review you can't manage to do it in a reasonable amount of time. 1 minute late could cost you a raise. Many of your "colleagues" that you'll never meet are unprepared or unqualified.
reviews.pros: Flexible hours, pays on time (often early), if you make a mistake on an invoice they'll still pay what they owe you. Regular pay raises, but...

reviews.advice: not all students are truthful about scores - honor your contracts - staff not friendly - expect no raises
reviews.cons:
Four raises in ten years - do not value dependible realiable teacher with no call out no late cancellation  its scores scores which students can manipulate - or use there personal feeling to destroy a teacher. 
New management is selective and didn't support teachers who have been there longer
Used favoritism with new teachers...never once received thank you for being two years..or five years only accolades for new teachers pets - only communication with teachers is most of the time negative except if you work for corporate or you were hired with new management
reviews.pros: Best working hours - work from home - meet great people around the world
